definition: Li Si (c. 280-208 BC), Legalist philosopher, calligrapher and prime minister of Qin kingdom and Qin dynasty from 246 to 208 BC
plum
surname Li
(phonetic)/this
Slovakia/Slovak/abbr. for 斯洛伐克[Si1 luo4 fa2 ke4]
Ferenc (Franz) Liszt (1811-1886), Hungarian composer/Joseph Lister (1883-1897), British surgeon and bacteriologist

sentences.english: Did you meet a young actor by the name of Tom Ress yesterday?
sentences.chinese: 昨天你見到那個湯姆，李斯的年輕演員了嗎？

sentences.english: Objective To investigate the contamination status of foods by L. monocytogenes.
sentences.chinese: 目的瞭解冷藏冷凍食品中李斯特菌污染狀況。

sentences.english: When she finished playing the piano, Liszt pointed out a few small mistakes.
sentences.chinese: 她彈完琴後，李斯特給她指出了多少個小毛病。

sentences.english: When I'm with Liz, I feel like a different person.
sentences.chinese: 當我和李斯在一起的時候，我感覺就像是另外一個人。

sentences.english: Allow me to introduce our manager, Stone Lee.
sentences.chinese: 請允許我介紹一下我們的經理，李斯通先生。

sentences.english: Listeria monocytogenes and Salmonella than some of the common E. coli are more lethal.
sentences.chinese: 李斯特菌比常見的沙門氏菌和某些大腸桿菌更爲致命。

sentences.english: Liebestraume means "Dream of Love" in German.
It left England to go to Virginia.
sentences.chinese: 在維吉尼亞古老的李斯堡過夜很好。

sentences.english: Some of Mozart and Beethoven's early works, Chopin, Liszt.
sentences.chinese: 莫扎特和貝多芬的早期作品，肖邦，李斯特。

sentences.english: Among the cognoscenti Liszt provoked more criticism than praise.
sentences.chinese: 在行家眼光中，李斯特所招致的批評遠比讚美來的多。

sentences.english: The achievement of Song (Sacrificial Songs) of the Qing dynasty is represented by Lis's seven pieces of Stone inscription.
sentences.chinese: 秦代頌體文學成就體現在李斯七篇刻石文上。

sentences.english: Oleg Maisenberg will close the festival with works of Liszt and Schubert.
sentences.chinese: 奧列格邁森貝格將關閉與李斯特和舒伯特的作品節日。

sentences.english: I represent Reese Computer and Supply Company.
sentences.chinese: 我代表李斯電腦供應公司。

sentences.english: Stone Lee killed his wife because she nagged him nonstop for 20 years.
sentences.chinese: 李斯通殺死了他的太太，因爲她不停地嘮叨了20午。

sentences.english: Retiree Jerrell McAlister says saving others is more important than a vacation.
sentences.chinese: 退休的麥阿李斯特說，幫助他人比度假更重要。

sentences.english: Ron Artest can rinse with Listerine for 60 seconds.
sentences.chinese: 阿泰含着李斯特防腐液60秒來漱口。

definition: Zhao Gao (?-207 BC), one of the most vile, corrupt and powerful eunuchs in Chinese history, responsible for the fall of Qin Dynasty

Lü Buwei (?291-235 BC), merchant and politician of the State of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], subsequent Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin2 dai4] Chancellor, allegedly the father of Ying Zheng 嬴政[Ying2 Zheng4], who subsequently became the first emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]
Han Fei, also known as Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3] (c. 280-233 BC), Legalist philosopher of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)

Wei Lao (c. 450 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), advisor to the first Qin emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], possible author of the Wei Liaozi 尉繚子|尉缭子[Wei4 Liao2 zi5] text on military strategy
Qin general Meng Tian (-210 BC), involved in 215 BC in fighting the Northern Xiongnu 匈奴 and building the great wall

Shang Yang (c. 390-338 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of the state of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], whose reforms paved the way for the eventual unification of the Chinese empire by the Qin dynasty 秦朝|秦朝[Qin2 chao2]
Su Qin (340-284 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
the most senior minister of many kingdoms or dynasties (with varying roles)/prime minister
Qin Ershi (229-207 BC), second Qin emperor
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Duke Xiao of Qin, 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], ruled 361-338 BC during the Warring States Period
Xiao He (-193 BC), famous strategist and chancellor, fought on Liu Bang's 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] side during the Chu-Han Contention 楚漢戰爭|楚汉战争[Chu3 Han4 Zhan4 zheng1]
Zhou Bo (?-169 BC), military man and politician at the Qin-Han transition, a founding minister of Western Han
Qin Shihuang (259-210 BC), the first emperor
prime minister (in ancient China)
Jia Yi (200-168 BC), Chinese poet and statesman of the Western Han Dynasty
